title: Grants small city school districts the authority to provide cafeteria services to students should such district be subject to a contingency budget
summary: Grants small city school districts the authority to provide cafeteria or restaurant services to students should such district be subject to a contingency budget.

S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K
       ________________________________________________________________________

                                         1514

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                   I N  S E N A T E

                                   January 10, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced  by Sens. KLEIN, OPPENHEIMER -- read twice and ordered print-
         ed, and when printed to be committed to the Committee on Education

       AN ACT to amend the education law, in relation to  granting  small  city
         school  districts  the  authority  to  provide  cafeteria  services to
         students should such district be subject to a contingency budget

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section  1. Paragraph a of subdivision 9 of section 2503 of the educa-
    2  tion law, as amended by chapter 171 of the laws of 1996, is  amended  to
    3  read as follows:
    4    a.  Shall  promote  the best interests of the schools and other activ-
    5  ities committed to its care, and shall authorize, or in  its  discretion
    6  conduct,  and  maintain  such  extra classroom activities, including the
    7  operation of cafeterias or restaurant service  for  use  by  pupils  and
    8  teachers,  as  the  board,  from  time to time, shall deem proper.  Such
    9  cafeterias or restaurant service may be used by the community for school
   10  related functions and activities and to furnish  meals  to  the  elderly
   11  residents,  sixty  years of age or older, of the district. Such utiliza-
   12  tion BY COMMUNITY OR ELDERLY RESIDENTS shall be subject to the  approval
   13  of the board of education, and shall be subject to voter approval unless
   14  the  cafeteria  or  restaurant service was operated during the preceding
   15  school year and requires no tax levy. Charges  shall  be  sufficient  to
   16  meet  the  direct cost of preparing and serving such meals, reducible by
   17  available reimbursements.
   18    S 2. Subdivision 5 of section 2601-a of the education law, as  amended
   19  by  section  29 of part A of chapter 436 of the laws of 1997, is amended
   20  to read as follows:
   21    5. If the qualified voters fail or refuse to vote the sum estimated to
   22  be necessary  for  teachers'  salaries  and  other  ordinary  contingent
   23  expenses,  the board shall adopt a contingency budget in accordance with
   24  this subdivision and shall levy a tax  for  that  portion  of  such  sum

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD04850-01-1

       S. 1514                             2

    1  remaining  after  applying thereto the moneys received or to be received
    2  from state, federal or other sources, in the same manner as if the budg-
    3  et had been approved by the qualified voters; subject to the limitations
    4  imposed in subdivision four of section two thousand twenty-three of this
    5  [chapter] TITLE and this subdivision. The administrative component shall
    6  not comprise a greater percentage of the contingency budget exclusive of
    7  the capital component than the lesser of (1) the percentage the adminis-
    8  trative  component  had  comprised in the prior year budget exclusive of
    9  the capital component; or (2) the percentage the  administrative  compo-
   10  nent had comprised in the last proposed defeated budget exclusive of the
   11  capital  component. Such contingency budget shall include the sum deter-
   12  mined by the board to be necessary for:
   13    (a) teachers' salaries, including the salaries of all members  of  the
   14  teaching and supervising staff;
   15    (b) items of expense specifically authorized by statute to be incurred
   16  by  the  board of education, including, but not limited to, expenditures
   17  for transportation to and from regular school programs included as ordi-
   18  nary contingent expenses in subdivision twelve  of  section  twenty-five
   19  hundred  three  of  this  [chapter]  TITLE,  expenditures for textbooks,
   20  required  services  for  non-public  school  students,   school   health
   21  services,  special  education  services, kindergarten and nursery school
   22  programs, and the district's share of the administrative costs and costs
   23  of services provided by a board of cooperative educational services;
   24    (c) items of expense for legal obligations of the district, including,
   25  but not limited to, contractual obligations, debt service, court  orders
   26  or judgments, orders of administrative bodies or officers, and standards
   27  and  requirements of the board of regents and the commissioner that have
   28  the force and effect of law;
   29    (d) the purchase of library books and  other  instructional  materials
   30  associated with a library;
   31    (e) items of expense necessary to maintain the educational programs of
   32  the  district,  preserve  the  property  of  the district or protect the
   33  health and safety of students and staff, including, but not limited  to,
   34  support  services,  pupil personnel services, the necessary salaries for
   35  the  necessary  number  of  non-teaching  employees,   necessary   legal
   36  expenses,  water  and utility charges, instructional supplies for teach-
   37  ers' use, emergency repairs, temporary  rental  of  essential  classroom
   38  facilities,  and expenditures necessary to advise school district voters
   39  concerning school matters; [and]
   40    (f) expenses incurred for interschool athletics, field trips and other
   41  extracurricular activities; [and]
   42    (g) THE EXPENSE OF CAFETERIA AND RESTAURANT SERVICES USED  BY  PUPILS,
   43  TEACHERS  AND STAFF. CAFETERIAS OR RESTAURANT SERVICE USED BY THE COMMU-
   44  NITY FOR SCHOOL RELATED FUNCTIONS AND ACTIVITIES AND TO FURNISH MEALS TO
   45  THE ELDERLY RESIDENTS SHALL NOT BE PART OF A CONTINGENCY  BUDGET  UNLESS
   46  NO TAX LEVY IS REQUIRED TO SUPPORT SUCH SERVICE; AND
   47    (H)  any other item of expense determined by the commissioner to be an
   48  ordinary contingent expense in any school district.
   49    S 3. Subdivision 1 of section 2023 of the education law, as amended by
   50  chapter 682 of the laws of 2002, is amended to read as follows:
   51    1. If the qualified voters shall neglect or refuse  to  vote  the  sum
   52  estimated  necessary  for teachers' salaries, after applying thereto the
   53  public school moneys, and other moneys received or to  be  received  for
   54  that  purpose,  or if they shall neglect or refuse to vote the sum esti-
   55  mated necessary for ordinary contingent expenses, including the purchase
   56  of library books and other instructional  materials  associated  with  a

       S. 1514                             3

    1  library and expenses incurred for interschool athletics, field trips and
    2  other  extracurricular  activities  and  the  expenses  for cafeteria or
    3  restaurant services USED BY PUPILS, TEACHERS AND STAFF, the  sole  trus-
    4  tee,  board of trustees, or board of education shall adopt a contingency
    5  budget including such expenses and shall levy a tax  for  the  same,  in
    6  like  manner  as  if  the  same  had been voted by the qualified voters,
    7  subject to the limitations contained in subdivisions three and  four  of
    8  this section.
    9    S  4.  This act shall take effect on the first of July next succeeding
   10  the date on which it shall have become a law.
